arguments.claim: The Sales Tax Tribunal could only decide disputes between the assessee and the Commissioner in terms of the provisions of the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939, and the question of ultra vires was foreign to its jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: This court in K. S. Venkataraman Co. P. Ltd. v. State of Madras Civil Appeal No. 618 of 1963 decided on October 18, 1965 held that the Sales Tax Tribunal could only decide disputes between the assessee and the Commissioner in terms of the provisions of the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939, and the question of ultra vires was foreign to its jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: This is a fit case for excusing the delay in filing the special leave petitions

anchor.surface_text: Without deciding whether they were barred or not, on that there is some dispute, we think, having regard to the circumstances of the case, that this is a fit case for excusing the delay, if any. We accordingly excuse the delay in filing the special leave petitions.

holdings.text: We accordingly excuse the delay in filing the special leave petitions.

holdings.text: we must hold that the question raised by the appellant before the High Court could not be decided by the sales tax authorities under the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: For the same reason, we must hold that the question raised by the appellant before the High Court could not be decided by the sales tax authorities under the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947.

holdings.reasoning_summary: For the same reason as held in K. S. Venkataraman Co. P. Ltd. v. State of Madras where Sales Tax Tribunal could only decide disputes in terms of the Act and ultra vires was foreign to its jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The High Court, therefore, went wrong in dismissing the applications on the ground that the appellant should exhaust his internal remedies under the said Act.
